title: North Devon soap making course is proving popular
text:
North Devon soap making course is proving popular X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Sarah picks natural ingredients for her soaps Handmade soaps Comments (0) 
Sarah Harper makes her own soaps and also runs classes in a picturesque North Devon location, Mike Bramhall writes 
If you want some good, clean fun while learning an ancient art, why not slip into a soap-making master class in one of the Westcountry's most picturesque locations? 
People from across the country are already in a lather after learning the secrets of soap from skilled craftswoman Sarah Harper. 
And with Christmas looming, many more from across the South West are signing up for the range of craft activities she runs from her Rowan Tree Studio workshop in Clovelly, North Devon. Related content 17 Christmas craft ideas you can do with all the family 
These include workshops on candle-making, dressmaking, furniture painting and patchwork and quilting. 
But it is soap, and the opportunity to learn how to make it yourself, which is proving massively popular as people increasingly turn away from chemicals in commercial cleaners and opt instead to put simple, natural ingredients onto their skin. 
Indeed, it was after developing a chemical sensitivity and allergies to commercial shower gels, skincare and cleaning products that led Devon-born Sarah to turn her back on a finance career in London and launch her workshops and her own soap-making company. 
Born in Barnstaple, she grew up in South Molton before moving to Hertfordshire at the age of 11. After studying psychology at university in Leicester, she moved to London. 
Sarah said: "I was working in the City as a client relationship manager, dealing with banks. It was high-powered and very stressful. 
"I realised after five years that working in that environment was not for me, and decided to find a way to work for myself." 
It was at that point that fate took a hand. She said: "I had developed skin sensitivity and lots of allergies. Someone had bought me a book on soap-making, and I decided to give it a go. 
"I really enjoyed it, and after a while I decided to quit my job and make soap for a living." 
She re-trained as a massage therapist to keep some money coming in, and with husband Casie took on a variety of jobs including dog-walking and pet-sitting while honing her soap-making techniques. 
Working from her kitchen table, Sarah started selling her soaps at craft fairs before eventually winning orders from a couple of London stockists. One of the shops then opened a craft studio, where Sarah was invited to teach sewing, candle-making and soap-making. 
She said: "That's when we hatched a plot to leave London and go into business somewhere else. It was a toss-up between Devon and Scotland, where we had holidayed, but in the end Devon won – it was nearer and I still had family there." 
In 2011, she moved to the Clovelly estate, where the family moved into a former grain store which had been converted into a living and working space, with a purpose-built studio for classes and rooms for soap making. 
The estate also gave the business its new name, and with a rebrand and new website The Clovelly Soap Company was born. 
Sarah uses her studio to teach the secrets of soap-making. She said: "Soap-making is probably the most popular of the courses we run. People come from all over the country to learn. 
"Some want to do it for a hobby, some for a one-off experience, while others want to learn what they need to do to create their own business. 
"Part of the attraction is that we only use natural products. 
"People are becoming more aware of the chemicals in modern products – they want to know what they are putting on their skin and to make soap for themselves and for Christmas presents." 
Finding the magic ingredients 
According to Sarah, the principles of soap-making have not change for hundreds of years. 
The base is a blend of oils, such as olive or coconut oil, which are then blended with a catalyst, sodium hydroxide. 
This is then mixed with other natural 'ingredients' such as herbs, plants, oils and clays and left to 'cook' overnight to form the familiar block of soap. 
Sarah, the mother of two daughters aged seven and one, said: "On our courses we spend the morning talking about the background of soap-making, what it used to be used for and how it has now been replaced by detergents. 
"Then we talk about equipment, methods and trouble-shooting. People work in pairs, and at the end of they day they take home around 30 bars of soap they have made. 
"We have 20 soaps in our range, but we have a range of ingredients and people can blend their own creations. 
"We encourage people to use what they have got. For example some people keep goats, and they can use goat's milk in their soap. Bee-keepers can use honey and beeswax." 
The courses also cover candle making and other natural products including creams, body butters and bath bombs. 
Sarah has written The Natural & Handmade Soap Book, containing 20 recipes for bath soaps, shampoo bars, homemade washing powder and dishwasher soap bombs. 
For more information about this, and the range of courses she runs, see www.rowantreestudio.co.uk
